name: threat-group-3390

procedures: T1003.001::[Threat Group-3390] actors have used a modified version of [Mimikatz] called Wrapikatz to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.
T1003.002::[Threat Group-3390] actors have used [gsecdump] to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.
T1003.004::[Threat Group-3390] actors have used [gsecdump] to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.
T1005::[Threat Group-3390] ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.
T1012::A [Threat Group-3390] tool can read and decrypt stored Registry values.
T1016::[Threat Group-3390] actors use [NBTscan] to discover vulnerable systems.
T1018::[Threat Group-3390] has used the net view command.
T1021.006::[Threat Group-3390] has used WinRM to enable remote execution.
T1027.002::[Threat Group-3390] has packed malware and tools, including using VMProtect.

T1027::A [Threat Group-3390] tool can encrypt payloads using XOR. [Threat Group-3390] malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.
T1030::[Threat Group-3390] actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.
T1033::[Threat Group-3390] has used `whoami` to collect system user information.
T1046::[Threat Group-3390] actors use the Hunter tool to conduct network service discovery for vulnerable systems.
T1047::A [Threat Group-3390] tool can use WMI to execute a binary.
T1049::[Threat Group-3390] has used `net use` and `netstat` to conduct internal discovery of systems. The group has also used `quser.exe` to identify existing RDP sessions on a victim.
T1053.002::[Threat Group-3390] actors use [at] to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install [HTTPBrowser] or [PlugX] on other victims on a network.
T1055.012::A [Threat Group-3390] tool can spawn `svchost.exe` and inject the payload into that process.
T1056.001::[Threat Group-3390] actors installed a credential logger on Microsoft Exchange servers. [Threat Group-3390] also leveraged the reconnaissance framework, ScanBox, to capture keystrokes.
T1059.001::[Threat Group-3390] has used PowerShell for execution.
T1059.003::[Threat Group-3390] has used command-line interfaces for execution.
T1068::[Threat Group-3390] has used CVE-2014-6324 and CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges.
T1070.004::[Threat Group-3390] has deleted existing logs and exfiltrated file archives from a victim.
T1070.005::[Threat Group-3390] has detached network shares after exfiltrating files, likely to evade detection.
T1071.001::[Threat Group-3390] malware has used HTTP for C2.
T1074.001::[Threat Group-3390] has locally staged encrypted archives for later exfiltration efforts.
T1074.002::[Threat Group-3390] has moved staged encrypted archives to Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with [China Chopper] prior to exfiltration.
T1078::[Threat Group-3390] actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.
T1087.001::[Threat Group-3390] has used net user to conduct internal discovery of systems.
T1105::[Threat Group-3390] has downloaded additional malware and tools, including through the use of `certutil`, onto a compromised host .
T1112::A [Threat Group-3390] tool has created new Registry keys under `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\` and `HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services`.
T1119::[Threat Group-3390] ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.
T1133::[Threat Group-3390] actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services.
T1140::During execution, [Threat Group-3390] malware deobfuscates and decompresses code that was encoded with Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.
T1189::[Threat Group-3390] has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.
T1190::[Threat Group-3390] has exploited the Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 and CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 in Exchange Server.
T1195.002::[Threat Group-3390] has compromised the Able Desktop installer to gain access to victim's environments.
T1199::[Threat Group-3390] has compromised third party service providers to gain access to victim's environments.
T1203::[Threat Group-3390] has exploited CVE-2018-0798 in Equation Editor.
T1204.002::[Threat Group-3390] has lured victims into opening malicious files containing malware.
T1210::[Threat Group-3390] has exploited MS17-010 to move laterally to other systems on the network.
T1505.003::[Threat Group-3390] has used a variety of Web shells.
T1543.003::[Threat Group-3390]'s malware can create a new service, sometimes naming it after the config information, to gain persistence.
T1547.001::[Threat Group-3390]'s malware can add a Registry key to `Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run` for persistence.
T1548.002::A [Threat Group-3390] tool can use a public UAC bypass method to elevate privileges.
T1555.005::[Threat Group-3390] obtained a KeePass database from a compromised host.
T1560.002::[Threat Group-3390] has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.
T1562.002::[Threat Group-3390] has used appcmd.exe to disable logging on a victim server.
T1566.001::[Threat Group-3390] has used e-mail to deliver malicious attachments to victims.
T1567.002::[Threat Group-3390] has exfiltrated stolen data to Dropbox.
T1574.001::[Threat Group-3390] has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.
T1574.002::[Threat Group-3390] has used DLL side-loading, including by using legitimate Kaspersky antivirus variants as well as `rc.exe`, a legitimate Microsoft Resource Compiler.
T1583.001::[Threat Group-3390] has registered domains for C2.
T1588.002::[Threat Group-3390] has obtained and used tools such as [Impacket], [pwdump], [Mimikatz], [gsecdump], [NBTscan], and [Windows Credential Editor].
T1588.003::[Threat Group-3390] has obtained stolen valid certificates, including from VMProtect and the Chinese instant messaging application Youdu, for their operations.
T1608.001::[Threat Group-3390] has hosted malicious payloads on Dropbox.
T1608.002::[Threat Group-3390] has staged tools, including [gsecdump] and WCE, on previously compromised websites.
T1608.004::[Threat Group-3390] has embedded malicious code into websites to screen a potential victim's IP address and then exploit their browser if they are of interest.

description: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) is a Chinese threat group that has extensively used strategic Web compromises to target victims.(Citation: Dell TG-3390) The group has been active since at least 2010 and has targeted organizations in the aerospace, government, defense, technology, energy, manufacturing and gambling/betting sectors.(Citation: SecureWorks BRONZE UNION June 2017)(Citation: Securelist LuckyMouse June 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
